awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Interaction between Violence and Perception of Social Difference
awd_abstract_narration:
Identity-based violence - violence directed at individuals or groups perceived as divergent - often accompanies periods of socio-political upheaval. While a growing body of anthropological and behavioral research demonstrates that the perception of social difference can motivate instances of mass violence today, little work has been done to examine such identity-based violence archaeologically. This may be because the subtleties of distinct social identities can be difficult to interpret in the past. A bioarchaeological approach, however, is well suited to empirically reconstruct past individuals' social identities, as many facets of identity such as age, sex, or biological relatedness, are grounded in the physical body, while others leave traces on the body through behavior, such as dietary preferences or cultural modification. This research will support both graduate and undergraduate student training and enhance international research partnerships and collaborations between the United States and Mexico. Furthermore, it will contribute to broader anthropological understandings of how instances of mass violence may arise from the interaction between specific social identities and complex social processes of migration, demographic change, and biological relatedness.


Using a combination of biogeochemical and biodistance analyses, this project reconstructs the residential histories and biological kinship affiliations of victims of human sacrifice interred at a small shrine site in pre-Hispanic central Mexico. The shrine site dates to the Epiclassic period (600-900 CE). In central Mexico, this period was characterized by the decline of the major regional center of Teotihuacán and was a time of dramatic political, social, and demographic reorganization. In such a volatile socio-political landscape, individuals' residential histories or kinship affiliations may have singled them out as targets of ritual violence. This research will answer the question: how did specific aspects of individuals' social identities predispose them to suffer ritual violence? The biogeochemical analysis of dental and skeletal elements from a sample of 72 individuals will allow this project to reconstruct the geographic origins of the sacrificial victims, while biodistance analyses will allow for the reconstruction of patterns of genetic relatedness among the sacrificial victims themselves, as well as between the sacrificial victims and contemporary populations in central Mexico

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates identity-based violence—violence directed at individuals perceived as different or "other"—at a mass human sacrifice event in pre-Hispanic central Mexico. While scholars have studied the cosmological motivations for and socio-political underpinnings of ritual violence in this region, relatively little is known about the sacrificial victims themselves. Were certain people more liable to become sacrificial victims? Who was more likely to be targeted for such violence?

In this project, we examined if and how different categorical social identities predisposed people to suffer ritual violence during a period of socio-political upheaval. We analyzed the human skeletal remains from an Epiclassic (600-900 CE) pre-Hispanic shrine site in the marshes of the northern Basin of Mexico. At this site, a minimum of 173 individuals were ritually sacrificed: their throats were slit and their decapitated heads were buried underneath the shrine platform. We used archaeological chemistry and biodistance analyses to reconstruct sacrificial victims’ residential histories as well as their kinship ties and ethnic affiliations to determine whether individuals who were perceived as divergent or “other” were overrepresented among the sacrificial victims.

Chemical analyses of the sacrificial victims’ skeletal remains demonstrated that socially divergent individuals made up a large proportion of the sacrificial victims. By analyzing the isotopic make up of multiple bone and enamel tissues forming at different times throughout the life course of each individual, we were able to reconstruct sacrificial victims’ geographic origins and residential histories. In pre-Hispanic central Mexico, peoples’ geographic place of origin was an important signifier of social identity and social difference. Interestingly, isotopic analyses of bone and enamel tissues from a sample of sacrificial victims (n=73) indicated that a majority of the victims were not from the Basin of Mexico: 52% of sampled individuals were immigrants who were born outside the Basin but moved to the region later in life; 23% were foreigners who were born and lived outside the Basin most of their lives; 8% were circular migrants who were born in the Basin, but would leave and return periodically; and finally, just 16% of sacrificial victims were locals who were born and lived in the Basin of Mexico their entire lives. The high proportion of immigrant and foreign individuals and the low proportion of locals among the sacrificial victims suggests that individuals were likely targeted for violence based on their divergent residential histories and geographic origins that would have marked them as different from local populations.

Biodistance analyses paint a similar picture. By analyzing similarities and differences in sacrificial victims’ tooth shape and size, we were able to reconstruct patterns of biological kinship among victims as well as victims’ ethnic affiliations with contemporaneous Mesoamerican populations. Results indicated that multiple different kin-groups were represented among the sacrificial victims. Moreover, none of these kin-groups were likely ethnically affiliated with concomitant populations in the Basin of Mexico. While analyses are still on-going, initial results suggest that sacrificial victims were more biologically similar to populations living in southern and western Mexico. These findings fit nicely with the distinct geographic origins and residential histories of the sacrificial victims. Taken together, these results represent conclusive evidence of identity-based violence in the past, suggesting that being perceived as socially “other” did indeed predispose individuals to higher risks of suffering ritual violence.

This project thus not only improved knowledge of Mesoamerican traditions of human sacrifice and ritual violence, but also contributed to broader anthropological understandings of identity-based violence and how instances of mass violence may arise from the interaction between specific social identities and complex social processes such as migration, demographic change, and biological relatedness. This latter contribution is particularly relevant as many of these same processes are evident today in the rising tides of nationalism, xenophobia, and identity-based violence around the world in response to increasing globalization, demographic change, and mass migration. By learning from and understanding such processes—as well as their gruesome and violent consequences—in the past, we can hope to avoid making similar mistakes in the present and future.
